ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK TAR: OTH 37760 
 
                   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
(Financed from the Japan Special Fund) 
 
FOR THE 
 
ASEAN+3 REGIONAL SETTLEMENT LINKAGE  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
December 2003

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ABMI  –  Asian Bond Market Initiative 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ASEAN+3  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations plus People’s 
Republic of China, Japan, and Republic of Korea 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  FXSI  –  Foreign Exchange and Settlement Issues 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by M. Miyachi, F.C. Kawawaki, and C.Y. Park.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  is  a  member  of  the  working  group  on  Foreign 
Exchange and Settlement Issues (FXSI) created under the Forum of Finance Ministers of the 
Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and People’s Republic of China, Japan, and 
Republic of Korea (ASEAN+3) under the ASEAN+3 Asian Bond Market Initiative (ABMI). ADB has 
been requested to support the FXSI’s work by conducting a study on possibly linking the bond 
settlement systems within the region. As this reflects recent developments in the discussion on the 
subject, the Technical Assistance (TA) was not included in last year's Subregional Cooperation 
Strategy and Program: Status Report for the Southeast Asia region or the Mekong region. The 
President approved the TA's concept clearance on 5 December 2003.1 The design of the TA was 
discussed with the concerned countries at the  working group meeting in Kuala Lumpur on 21 
November 2003 and reported at the Deputy Finance and Central Bank Officer's Meeting for 
ASEAN+3 in Seoul on 28 November 2003. The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The Asian Financial Crisis that began in 1997 had a significant impact on the people in the 
region. The surge in poverty incidence in the region in the aftermath of the Crisis has been well 
documented. The mismatch in maturity and currency between debt and revenue for borrowers in 
the region is one of the key causes of the Crisis.. The excessive dependence on bank financing 
without effective governance and alternative sources of funds created the situation where domestic 
banks  and  companies  borrowed  in  short  term  foreign  currency  for  long-term  local  currency 
generating projects.  Although the region has experienced remarkable recovery, without a well-
developed, efficient source of long-term local currency, these mismatches remain a major source 
of financial vulnerability in the region.  
 
3.   The ASEAN+3 and other forums, including the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC), 
have been trying to address this issue through the development of domestic and regional bond 
markets. For this purpose, the ASEAN+3 countries endorsed the ABMI at the ASEAN+3 deputies 
meeting in Chiang Mai, Thailand, on 17 December 2002. The ABMI emphasizes the need for a 
joint and comprehensive set of actions by the ASEAN+3 countries  to develop domestic and 
regional bond markets in two broad areas: (i) facilitating access to the market by a wide variety of 
issuers, and (ii) creating an environment conducive to developing domestic and regional bond 
markets. Six working groups have been set up to examine the factors necessary for bond market 
development.2  These working groups are expected to provide input into the decision making by 
the finance ministers of ASEAN+3. ADB has been a member of the all the  voluntary working 
groups inception.   The efforts of the ASEAN+3 group should have a demonstrative on countries 
outside the group. 
 
4.  Since February 2003,  the  working  groups  have  discussed  the various impediments to 
domestic and regional bond market development.  Through these discussions ADB has been 
requested to provide various support including the request for this TA.  For the working group on 
credit  guarantee  mechanism,  ADB  is  providing  assistance  through  a  study  on  the  regional

guarantee  mechanism.3   The  local  and  regional  rating  agencies  working  group  have  been 
supported by ADB's coordination with Asian Credit Rating Agencies Association and also have 
requested ADB  to provide support for the establishment of an Asian Bonds Online Website.4    
ADB has co-hosted a seminar in Beijing for the issuance of local currency bonds by nondomestic 
issuers.    As  for  other  institutions,  the  ASEAN  Secretariat  is  administering  bilateral  technical 
assistance and Bank of Japan has  volunteered to conduct a survey on the enabling factors, 
impediments and issues relating to foreign exchange transactions and settlement issues. 
 
5.      The absence of a cohesive linkage of bond clearing mechanisms in the region is adversely 
affecting cross border investments  and thus the  development of  domestic and regional bond 
markets. This results in more costly and less timely clearance of bond instruments. The lack of an 
efficient  clearing  mechanism  reflects  the  insufficient  volume  of  transactions  to  justify  the 
establishment  of  a  cross  border  settlement  system,  however  in  turn  it  also  constrains  the 
development of the bond market.  Without a secure, timely, and cost effective system, the recycling 
of savings into investments in the region is severely hampered in the primary and secondary 
markets.   
 
6.   In  January  1997,  ADB  commissioned  a  study  on  strengthening  clearing  and  settlement 
systems for bonds.  The study examined various options for providing efficient settlement in the 
region as well as recommended that ADB undertake a full study into the viability of custodian 
network. Several linkage options were ruled out  because of the  nacent state of the domestic 
system.  
 
7.      After  the  Crisis,  the  policy  makers  and  borrowers  have  realized  the  critical  role  that 
domestic bond markets play in the stable growth of their economies. At the country-level, there has 
been impressive improvement in the bond settlement and payment systems in the region.  The 
volumes of domestic issuance have increased significantly in the last few years. For example in 
1999, there were only few issuances in Indonesia as compared to USD 2.3 billion equivalent this 
year. Similarly, the markets have grown in  issuance volume in other ASEAN+3 countries, e.g.,  
USD 44 billion equivalent in PRC, USD 5 billion equivalent in Thailand, and  USD 1.9 billion 
equivalent in Malaysia this year. Along with the development of the domestic bond markets the 
settlement systems have been enhanced since the 1997 ADB study. Scriptless Registry and 
Settlement  and  delivery  against  payment  (DvP)  have  been  established  in  Indonesia.  DvP 
settlement is expected to be implemented in early 2004 in PRC. Hong Kong and Singapore have 
developed efficient systems with linkages to the international settlement systems, Euroclear and 
Clearstream.  Hong Kong has established  bilateral links with  Korea Settlement Deposit  and 
Austraclear  and  is  now  in  the  process  of  linking  with  Central  Depository  Company  (PRC).  
Singapore also has links with the international systems.  With the installation of cash payments of 
inter-bank  transactions,  the  introduction  of  DvP  based  settlement  of  securities  will  soon  be 
established in the Philippines.   
 
8.  The FXSI working group has therefore requested ADB to help identify the options and make 
recommendations for effectively accelerating the linkage of domestic settlement and payment 
systems to facilitate enhanced cross border investment. Since some domestic systems need to be 
enhanced for  such linkage, this would also provide impetus for improving local  settlement and 
clearing.

III.   THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
9.  The TA aims to reducing the financial  vulnerability in the region by contributing to the 
development of efficient regional and domestic bond markets in the region.  The specific objective 
of the TA is to assess the possibility of linking settlement systems in the region by examining the 
current status of bond settlement and identifying possible impediments to cross border investment, 
including a payment system and a foreign exchange settlement system. The TA will analyze the 
merits and demerits of linkage for each national system, keeping in mind that systems are in 
different stages of development in the ASEAN+3 countries.5  The TA will recommend options for 
linking the systems, and develop a possible implementation and preliminary business plan for the 
linkage.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  Through close consultation with private sector participants in the bond market and with 
policy makers,  the study will  assess the possibility of linking settlement systems in the region. 
Given the evolving nature of the capital markets, the design of the TA will be kept reasonably 
flexible so that it can meet the emerging needs of the domestic and regional bond markets. ADB 
will oversee the study in consultation with the FXSI working group under ABMI to ensure that the 
TA satisfies the objectives of the study. The consultants will review previous research and liaise 
with other working groups to benefit from their experience. The envisaged TA will comprise five 
components. 
 
  1.   Stocktaking of Currently Available Settlement Systems in the Region 
 
11.    The settlement systems in the region will be examined, and previous studies by ADB and 
other institutions  will  be  updated.    Because  a  detailed  study  has  been  undertaken  by  the 
Executives'  Meeting  of  East  Asia-Pacific  Central  Banks  (EMEAP)  organization,  an  in-depth 
investigation of each system will not be necessary.6   
 
  2.   Merits and Demerits of Linkage 
 
12.     The stage of development of each domestic system will determine how it will benefit from 
the linkage. The study will examine how  the linkage may  help improve  the efficiency of the 
settlement systems  and measures needed to overcome  any obstacles to the linkage.  Such 
obstacles may be technological, mechanical, regulatory, legal, or market practices.  
 
  3.       Analysis of Linkage In and Outside the Region 
 
13.  The examples of and experience with the methods of linkage in Europe and links already 
exist within the region will be analyzed to determine their applicability.

  4.   Possible Options for Linkage 
 
14.    ADB’s 1997 study on the possible creation of a regional clearing system put forth several 
options.7 The options included (i) a web model where the domestic settlement systems are linked 
directly to each other to create a network, and (ii) a hub model where all of the domestic systems 
are linked to a single hub.8 The study will look into these models and others to determine the best 
method of linkage; analyze the costs; and identify the legal, regulatory, and institutional hurdles 
and propose methods to overcome them.  Dialogue with the market participants and policy makers 
will be important to gauge the feasibility and financial viability of each option.  A presentation will be 
made on these options for discussion with the working group at a seminar.       
   
  5.   Recommended Option and Preliminary Business Plan 
 
15.  After  consultation  with  and  input  from  the  working  group,  the  best  option  will  be 
recommended together with a preliminary business plan for the linkage. The business plan will 
include the institutional or organizational structure, the contractual relationships between domestic 
systems,  and  the  scope  of  operational  relationships.    A  preliminary  demand  survey  will  be 
necessary  to  determine  the  system’s  financial  viability  in  line  with  the  expected  costs  of 
establishment.  A possible implementation plan will be determined, taking fully into account the 
different stages of development of the national settlement systems and improvement of these 
systems in the future. 
   
C.   Cost and Financing  
 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $300,000 equivalent. ADB will provide the entire 
amount on a  grant basis from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. 
Appendix 2 gives the details of the TA cost. The participating countries of the working group have 
financed the costs of preliminary activities,  and will  continue to  bear the ongoing costs of the 
working group.  
 
D.   Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA.  It will be administered by the Southeast Asia 
Department in coordination  with Mekong Department,  and Office of Cofinancing Operations. In 
consultation with the chair of the working group, ADB will supervise the work of the consultants.  
 
18.  Under  the  TA,  two  international  consultants  (a  settlement  and  payment  specialist  for 
4.5 person-months and a regional bond market specialist for 2.5 person months) will be engaged 
for a total of 7 person-months on an intermittent basis. They will be engaged by ADB as individual 
consultants following ADB’s Guidelines for the Use of Consulting Services. The consultants will 
have demonstrated and comprehensive experience related to bond markets and the development 
of  such  markets.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  consulting  services  are  presented  in 
Appendix 3.  
 
19.  The TA will begin in  January 2004 and will be completed by the end of June 2004. The 
consultants will prepare (i) an inception report, within 1 month of the TA’s start; (ii) an interim report, 
after the completion of the first four components within 4 months; (iii) a draft final report, within 
5 months; and (iv) a final report on completion of the study. A draft of the interim report will be

circulated for comments to the working group members. Upon receipt of the feedback on the draft 
report on the first four components, a seminar will be arranged to present the results to the working 
group in approximately April 2004. A draft final report with all five components will be circulated to 
the working group in May for comments. Upon receipt of the feedback, a second seminar will be 
arranged to present the final report to the working group around June 2004. The report will be used 
for further discussions and consideration of concrete actions for linking settlement systems in the 
region to facilitate the accelerated expansion of the bond market in the ASEAN+3 countries. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis for the 
ASEAN+3 Regional Settlement Linkage, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Bond Settlement and Clearance Specialist and Team Leader (4.5 person-months) 
 
1.   The specialist  will have had extensive experience in bond settlement and clearing 
systems. The specialist will coordinate with the other consultant to incorporate his or her views 
into the requested reports. The specialist will perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Update the current status of the bond settlement and clearing systems in the 
region with the background of the previous studies. 
 
(ii)  Examine and analyze the current linkage methods in and outside the region, 
including settlement systems in Europe and the interregional linkage. 
  
(iii)  Identify and analyze merits and demerits of linking the existing systems, including 
the  impediments  to  the  effectiveness  of  the  current  settlement  systems  for 
linkage with other systems and methods to overcome these.  The impediments 
may include legal, regulatory, and institutional hurdles. 
 
(iv)  Identify the options for linking the domestic systems in the region.  Examine the 
cost implications of the options.  Keep in mind the stages of development of the 
domestic systems.  Present the report on the options to the working group. 
 
(v)  With the input of the working group, recommend the best option.  Develop a 
preliminary  business  plan  for  an  institutional  or  organizational  structure,  the 
contractual relationships between domestic systems, and scope of operational 
relationships.    Incorporate  the  preliminary  demand  survey  to  determine  the 
financial viability in line with the expected costs of setting up the linkage system.  
Develop a possible implementation plan for the linkage, keeping in mind the 
different stages of development of the national systems.  
 
(vi)  Present the final report to the working group. 
 
(vii)  Perform other tasks reasonably requested by the Asian Development Bank. 
 
B.      Regional Bond Market Specialist (2.5 person-months) 
 
2.   The specialist will perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Assist  the  team  leader  in  updating  the  current  status  of  the  existing  bond 
settlement and clearing systems. 
 
(ii)  Assist the team leader to examine and analyze the current linkage methods in 
the region. 
 
(iii)  Assist the team leader in identifying and finding mitigating methods for the 
impediments to linkage.   
 
(iv)  Assist the team leader in determining the costs of the options for linkage.
